messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:36): othermaciej: my intent (unsure whether it's workable in reality) is for <h2>-<h6> to continue as is, for all the new block-level elements to have display:block as a style, and for <h1> to automatically style appropriately according to the section depth as defined by the outline section
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:37): othermaciej: but i have no idea if that is practical back-compat wise, let alone if it is implementable with good perf
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (07:38): hixie: did you get a chance to look at that event-source stuff yet?
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (07:38): oh wait i got an email back from you
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:01): oh heh actually i have another question about that

7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:03): if you have >1 RemoteEventTarget node within a single document, and they all get the same event source URI added to them, should the UA open one connection for each object, or just open one and then dispatch events from that connection to all the listeners?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:20): 7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967: i believe the spec unambiguously requires the former
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:22): hm. isn't there like a 2 HTTP connections per UA rule per server?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:22): yes, i wouldn't recommend that people have more than one of these things
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:23): yeah i suppose that makes sense
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:25): and is there like a pre-draft of what the Access-Control HTTP header might look like?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:35): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:35): www.w3.org/tr/access-control or some such
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:50): i guess this is the wrong place to ask this, but i don't understand what this is supposed to accomplish

7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:55): so i put a document on server-a.com, then another resource on server-b.com, and i want the server-a document to access the server-b resource....so now i have to make server-b.com provide an HTTP header that says it's ok for that to happen?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:56): yeah
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (08:56): how is this better than just having server-b check the Referer field?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:18): most servers don't check the referer field
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:19): so if we relied on that, most servers would be vulnerable today
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:19): but...zero servers check the Content-Access-Control fiel
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:19): no the server has to _send_ the field
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:19): i guess i'm not clear who's being protected here
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:20): the user is being protected from server-a pretending to be the user when talking to server-b
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:23): ah ok so this could prevent the resource from server-b, which is accessed by the user directly, from being sent back to server-a?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:24): right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:24): (on an unrelated note, http://www.w3.org/mid/<email/> summarises where i'm coming from regarding the wysiwyg stuff)
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:25): though it requires server-b to implement it, and the UA to implement it, and also requires breaking all other current cross-domain communication techniques?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:26): no
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:26): it requires server-b to implement it only if server-b wants to allow access
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:27): it requires the UA to implement it only if the UA is to support cross-domain stuff
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:27): and it doesn't affect any existing cross-domain features
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:30): ok but tricks like dom-inserting a <script> element could still get around this
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:31): dom-inserting a script only works if you're inserting a script
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:31): so yes, scripts aren't protected
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:38): ok but...let's say server-b doesn't want server-a's web pages from loading its images
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:38): it could say Content-Access-Control: deny server-a.com
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:39): but that would only be honored by new UAs
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:40): i mean i guess that's somewhat outside the scope of access control's purpose
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:41): but it's something of an broken-at-conception default behavior
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:50): 7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967: images are also not affected by this
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:51): 7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967: this doesn't affect anything that is allowed now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:51): 7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967: it only affects new cross-domain stuff
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:51): so it only applies in situations where the same origin policy is currently being used?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:51): it only applies in situations where the specs say it applies :-)

7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:52): yeah right so "To facilitate clear and controlled read access to resources, this specification defines a read access control mechanism that enables a web resource to permit access to its content from external domains when such access would otherwise be prohibited by a same origin policy."
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:52): i guess my question is....is there a formal definition of when the same origin policy is used?
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:53): i mean clearly it seems to always apply to XMLHttpRequest stuff
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:54): and presumably the event-source gunk
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:55): or is it just always left up the implementation?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:57): access-control only applies in situations where the specs explicitly say it applies
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:57): so e.g. xmlhttprequest
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:57): or rather xmlhttprequest2
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (09:58): ooo the sequel
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:58): because that spec says it applies
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:58): same with xbl2
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:58): xbl2 says it applies
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (10:01): well i guess that was a key point i was missing
7b55d0f261619a93f9ae615a3cb18967 (10:01): i thought it was more of a replacement for previous access control methods
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:04): nope
